title: Dispersions and Carbohydrates Quiz
description: Test your understanding of food dispersions and carbohydrates based on FNH 200 Chapter 2 content
subject: Food Science - Chemical & Physical Properties

questions.question: What is the maximum particle size for a substance to be classified as a food dispersion?

options.text: Less than 100 microns
Less than 600 microns
Less than 1000 microns
Less than 300 microns

questions.explanation: Food dispersions are characterized by small particle sizes less than 600 microns, which distinguishes them from coarser suspensions.

questions.question: Starch is digestible by humans but cellulose is not, despite both being polymers of glucose.
questions.explanation: Starch has α-1,4 glycosidic bonds that human enzymes can break, while cellulose has β-1,4 bonds that humans cannot digest due to lacking cellulase enzymes.

questions.question: Which monosaccharide has the highest sweetness index?

options.text: Glucose (sweetness index 70-80)
Fructose (sweetness index 140)
Galactose (sweetness index 60)
All have equal sweetness

questions.explanation: Fructose is the sweetest naturally occurring sugar with a sweetness index of 140, compared to glucose (70-80) and galactose (60).

questions.question: What type of dispersion is mayonnaise?

options.text: Water-in-oil (w/o) emulsion
Oil-in-water (o/w) emulsion
Gas-in-liquid foam
Solid-in-liquid sol

questions.explanation: Mayonnaise is an oil-in-water (o/w) emulsion where oil droplets (~75% of volume) are dispersed in vinegar (water phase) with egg yolk as the emulsifier.

questions.question: All three monosaccharides (glucose, fructose, and galactose) have the same molecular formula C₆H₁₂O₆.
questions.explanation: All three monosaccharides are isomers with the same molecular formula (C₆H₁₂O₆) but different structural arrangements, which affects their sweetness and properties.

questions.question: What is the role of egg yolk in mayonnaise?

options.text: It provides sweetness
It acts as an emulsifier containing lecithin
It adds color only
It serves as a preservative

questions.explanation: Egg yolk contains phospholipids (lecithin) that have both hydrophilic and lipophilic components, allowing them to stabilize the oil-water interface and prevent droplet coalescence.

questions.question: Match each dispersion type with its correct example:
questions.explanation: Sol = solid in liquid (starch solution), Gel = liquid in solid (jam), Foam = gas in liquid (whipped cream), Solid foam = gas in solid (bread).

questions.question: Why does lactose-free milk taste sweeter than regular milk despite having the same carbohydrate content?

options.text: Sugar is added during processing
Lactose is hydrolyzed to glucose and galactose, which have higher sweetness indices
The fat content is increased
Artificial sweeteners are added

questions.explanation: Lactose has a sweetness index of 10-20, but when hydrolyzed, the resulting glucose (70-80) and galactose (60) have higher sweetness indices, making the milk taste sweeter.

questions.question: What happens during starch gelatinization?

options.text: Starch granules shrink and harden
Heat and water cause granules to swell and burst, releasing starch molecules
Starch molecules crystallize
Water is expelled from the starch

questions.explanation: Gelatinization occurs when starch is heated with water: heat weakens bonds, water molecules form hydrogen bonds with starch, granules swell (60-70°C) and burst (complete by 85°C).

questions.question: Caramelization and Maillard browning are the same process.
questions.explanation: Caramelization involves heating sugar alone at high temperatures (110-203°C), while Maillard browning requires both a reducing sugar and amino compounds. Both are non-enzymatic browning reactions but occur through different mechanisms.

questions.question: Match each disaccharide with its component monosaccharides:
questions.explanation: Sucrose = glucose + fructose, Lactose = galactose + glucose, Maltose = glucose + glucose.

questions.question: How is high fructose corn syrup (HFCS) produced from starch?

options.text: Direct chemical conversion of starch to fructose
Starch → maltose (amylase) → glucose (maltase) → fructose (glucose isomerase)
Starch → glucose → sucrose → fructose
Fermentation of starch by yeast

questions.explanation: HFCS production involves three steps: (1) starch is hydrolyzed to maltose by amylase, (2) maltose is hydrolyzed to glucose by maltase, (3) glucose is isomerized to fructose by glucose isomerase enzyme.

questions.question: Why does invert sugar prevent candy from becoming brittle?

options.text: It is highly hygroscopic and attracts/retains moisture
It crystallizes more easily than sucrose
It adds structural strength to the candy
It prevents sugar molecules from bonding

questions.explanation: Invert sugar (glucose and fructose mixture) is highly hygroscopic, meaning it attracts and retains moisture. This prevents candies from drying out and becoming brittle.

questions.question: What is the main difference between amylose and amylopectin in starch?

options.text: Amylose is made of fructose while amylopectin is made of glucose
Amylose is linear while amylopectin is branched with α-1,6 branch points
Amylose is digestible while amylopectin is not
Amylose has β-bonds while amylopectin has α-bonds

questions.explanation: Amylose consists of linear glucose chains, while amylopectin has branched chains with α-1,6 branch points. Amylose contributes to gel formation while amylopectin contributes to viscosity.

questions.question: Sucrose is a reducing sugar and can directly participate in Maillard browning.
questions.explanation: Sucrose is a non-reducing sugar and cannot directly participate in Maillard browning. However, it can participate after being hydrolyzed by heat or acid to glucose and fructose, which are reducing sugars.

questions.question: What is starch retrogradation and how does it affect food?

options.text: The swelling of starch granules during heating
The recrystallization of amylose chains during cooling/storage, causing staling
The breakdown of starch into sugars
The initial gelatinization process

questions.explanation: Retrogradation occurs when linear amylose chains reorient into crystalline zones during cooling/storage, causing syneresis (water loss), toughening, and gritty texture (like stale bread). It's accelerated at refrigeration temperatures.

questions.question: Match each food gum with its primary source:
questions.explanation: Pectin comes from plant tissues, carrageenan from seaweed, xanthan gum from bacteria (Xanthomonas campestris), and gum arabic from tree sap.

questions.question: How do liquid-centered chocolates achieve their soft, syrupy center?

options.text: Liquid sugar syrup is injected after manufacturing
Invertase enzyme slowly converts crystalline sucrose to hygroscopic glucose-fructose mixture during storage
The chocolate melts and liquefies the center
Water is absorbed from the atmosphere

questions.explanation: Invertase enzyme is added to crystallized sucrose centers. During storage (ripening), the enzyme converts sucrose to the more hygroscopic glucose-fructose mixture (invert sugar), which doesn't crystallize easily and creates a soft, syrupy center.

questions.question: Why is the structural difference between starch and cellulose (α vs β bonds) critical for human nutrition?

options.text: It affects the taste of these compounds
Humans have enzymes that break α-1,4 bonds but lack enzymes for β-1,4 bonds
β bonds are toxic to humans
α bonds provide more calories than β bonds

questions.explanation: The α-1,4 bonds in starch can be broken by human digestive enzymes, making it a source of energy. The β-1,4 bonds in cellulose cannot be broken because humans lack cellulase enzymes, making cellulose indigestible dietary fiber despite both being glucose polymers.

questions.question: Honey has a 1:1 ratio of glucose to fructose because it contains invert sugar formed from sucrose by invertase.
questions.explanation: While honey does contain invert sugar formed by invertase in bee saliva, it has a 40:60 glucose:fructose ratio (not 1:1) because bees also forage on nectars containing other sugars besides sucrose.
